name: Subnauticat
desc: In this game, you play as a little explorer cat aboard a submarine that must go as deep as possible under water. To do this you have to suck up and sell treasures to then buy upgrades. The game was made in unity for the Brackeys Game Jam, theme: Diving Deeper, in just one week. I didn't know unity tilemaps very well before this project so I had to do some research in order to implement them.

contributions.desc: I programmed most of the mechanics of the game such as the upgrade system, movement and the save system. The upgrade system was a challenge for me because I had never saved so much data before.
In the project I had to be a level designer. I had to use the tilemap to create an interesting environment that pushes the player to buy the upgrades to go further.

name: Rest in Pastry
desc: Rest in Pastry is a game I made for 'My first game jam' in a bit less than two weeks. While working with a writer, two artists and a sound composer, I programmed the whole game. This gave me the opportunity to learn new things and to test my capacities.

contributions.desc: I've programmed every system in the game such as the dialogues, choosing the cooking options, serving the ghosts, the saving system and more..

name: C.H.O.M.
desc: C.H.O.M. is a Parkour/Shooter video game in a sci-fi environment that was made in Unity with C# in the context of a student project, I made it in a team with 3 other students over a period of 3 months. Working in an agile way (SCRUM) and participating in almost every aspect of video game design, it allowed me to gain experience and work in an industry-like way. My team and I also worked in collaboration with a small team of artists, which gave us a good understanding of the collaborative aspect of game creation. C.H.O.M. was only the first iteration of my journey in video game creation, I'm very ambitious about my future in the business. As you'll see below, although my part in the project was focused on programming, I was also heavily involved in the game's design.

contributions.desc: Parkour mechanics, enemy and projectile system, programming of the majority of the game's settings, level selection system, weapon dispensers, inspection showcases in the lobby and more...
Throughout the project, I had to repeatedly run tests to make sure that the mechanics worked well and were implemented as intended.
From start to finish, I was involved in the design of the game's levels, mechanics and environment.
